metadata.case_name: S. K. Dutt and Ors. v. State

facts.text: S. K. Dutt carried on business as British India Construction Company with branch at Asansol managed by J. K. Bose.
In May 1942, military construction of dumps and roads; R. W. Mathams was Garrison Engineer at Asansol, P. C. Ghose overseer under him.
Order placed with S. K. Dutt on or about 10th May 1942 for construction of dumps at Burnpur; works executed June-July 1942; Rs. 1,74,000 paid.
Prosecution alleged excess payment of Rs. 56,000 over works done.
Conspiracy: S. K. Dutt to claim roads constructed by military; Mathams to issue order; Ghose to measure and pass bill exceeding prior payments.
S. K. Dutt wrote Exhibit 19 on 28th January 1943 claiming payment for additional work.
Mathams passed order Exhibit 10 dated 7th July 1942 (alleged created March 1943) for road construction.
Ghose prepared final bill Exhibit 6 for Rs. 1,89,458-14-0 on 15th March 1943, passed by Mathams.
Roads alleged constructed by military, not S. K. Dutt.
Bribe of Rs. 30,000 agreed; S. K. Dutt sent cheque to J. K. Bose on 16th March 1943; paid Rs. 18,000 to Mathams and Rs. 12,000 to Ghose on 17th March 1943.
Appellants denied conspiracy; claimed roads constructed by S. K. Dutt; Rs. 30,000 for sub-contractors; produced Exhibit 27 series receipts.
Special Tribunal judgment 9th May 1946: acquitted conspiracy, convicted bribery.
High Court 14th July 1947: dismissed appellants' appeals, allowed Government appeal; convicted on both charges.
Mathams special leave from Privy Council 13th November 1947 on s.197 CrPC sanction.
Complaint 7th June 1945; prosecution witnesses 6th Sep 1945 to 29th Mar 1946.
J. K. Bose filed list of 15 witnesses on 27th March 1946; summons by ordinary post, not s.68/69; on 8th April 1946 Tribunal refused further process.
Federal Court 23rd April 1948: set aside convictions for s.257 CrPC violation; remanded for re-hearing with opportunity for witnesses.
High Court 2nd August 1948: adjourned till Mathams appeal disposal.
High Court 9th April 1951: fixed hearing 11th June 1951; steps for witnesses.
List filed 8th May 1951: addresses of only 6/15; B.C. Mukherjee and R.K. Paul examined; others unavailable (dead, migrated to East Pakistan, left place).
High Court 6th September 1951: convicted on both charges.

legal_issues.text: Whether the trial was vitiated by denial of reasonable opportunity to examine witnesses due to contravention of section 257 CrPC.
Whether sanction under section 197 CrPC was required for prosecution on charges of conspiracy and bribery.

petitioner_arguments.text: Roads constructed by S. K. Dutt using sub-contractors; Rs. 30,000 paid to sub-contractors per Exhibit 27 series receipts.

No reasonable opportunity to examine witnesses listed on 27th March 1946 due to Tribunal's refusal of process on 8th April 1946 and High Court's adjournments; most witnesses untraceable by 1951 due to war end, partition.

respondent_arguments.text: Excess payment Rs.56,000; fake road claim, backdated order; roads by military; bribe Rs.30,000 paid.
Witnesses' evidence rejected as they lack status; others fictitious.

court_reasoning.text: Federal Court held s.257 CrPC violated; witnesses material to rebut both charges via Exhibit 27.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Imperative terms of s.257; no reasons to refuse process.

court_reasoning.text: Delay due to Tribunal error and High Court adjournment (2nd Aug 1948); by 1951, witnesses untraceable due to post-war migration, partition; not appellants' fault.
Two witnesses real and examined; supports others real; unsafe to deem rest fictitious without evidence.
Prosecution case strong but appellants entitled to rebut; denial of opportunity = no fair trial.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Rules of procedure must be scrupulously followed.

court_reasoning.text: No sanction needed under s.197 CrPC per precedents.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Not concluded by H.H.B. Gill and Phanindra Chandra Neogy.

holdings.text: Convictions set aside due to contravention of s.257 CrPC and denial of fair trial.
No sanction required under s.197 CrPC for conspiracy and bribery charges.

precedents_cited.case_name: H. H. B. Gill v. The King
precedents_cited.relevance: No sanction under s.197 CrPC required.

precedents_cited.case_name: Phanindra Chandra Neogy v. The King
precedents_cited.relevance: No sanction under s.197 CrPC required.

statutes_cited.name: Criminal Procedure Code
statutes_cited.relevance: Sanction not required; s.257 imperative for witness process; violated leading to no fair trial.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Certificate for appeal to Supreme Court.

statutes_cited.name: Government of India Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Certificate for appeal to Federal Court.

outcome.summary: Appeals allowed; convictions of S.K. Dutt, J.K. Bose, P.C. Ghose and R.W. Mathams set aside; acquitted due to denial of fair trial from procedural irregularities preventing examination of material witnesses.

key_quotes.text: It is essential that rules of procedure designed to ensure justice, should be scrupulously followed, and Courts should be jealous in seeing that there is no breach of them.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Crux of holding on procedural fairness.

key_quotes.text: Whatever one may think of the merits of the appellants' contention, they cannot be convicted without an opportunity being given to them to present their evidence.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Emphasizes right to fair trial despite strong prosecution case.
